How to Rank Vulnerabilities in a Large Environment
‘How easy it is to exploit’ is a factor to rank vulnerability.

Information about the CVE is great, but I'd say no matter how you rank a vulnerability using all of that data, the only thing that can help you prioritize which ones to fix is a lot of context and correlation with other factors.- Is the asset publicly exposed- Does the asset contain or have access to sensitive data- Does the asset contain a useful secret (credentials, certificates, ssh keys, etc)- If it's a cloud asset, does it have an identity that could lead to lateral movement or account takeover- Assuming the asset gets compromised, what is the blast radius? What other assets are reachable by this asset?- What is the source of the vulnerability, and is that source in use in other places? Can I fix 100 instances of this vulnerability by fixing and redeploying one image?- Did the developer put a mitigation in place for this CVE already?- Does a fix for this CVE exist?That's just a short list. By the way, this is exactly what a CNAPP (cloud native application protection platform) like Wiz and Orca does for you.
EPSS + something to assess how critical the asset is, eg CVSS4.
Just use this https://www.cisa.gov/known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog
Should be risk-based. Start with the risks to business critical assets. If they go down, that = “no money” = “no job”.

The true risk of being exploited is the most important. We have a lot of high severity vulnerabilities but in reality the risk is low because they are not on machines exposed to the internet, so it’s more important to patch a lower severity vulnerability on an internet exposed machine in most cases.It also matters what data is stored on the machine and what lateral movement opportunities are associated with that machine. If we’re talking about a test server on an isolated network then honestly who cares?!
Use CISA KEV as your source of truth, no further prioritization needed, check out services that focus on it like www.oncyber.ca/paas.html or use a RBVM tool like Vulcan.io

Is it in the environment, is it forward facing or accessible? what is the attack path and complexity of attack? What is the mission impact of the affected software/system?Severity and patch difficulty should come last. While the vulnerability may not be severe it could be leveraged in some way as part of an attack.

Those are great factors. I might also include if there are any other mitigating controls such as a WAF in place providing protection.In any case you've got the right idea that you really do need to add your own context to figure out the priority.

It's important to think about the risk and exploit being available and exploit being actively utilised are really important as is the location of the device, if it's internal then you will have a number of mitigations and controls in place so focus on those internet facing services first.EPSS is up and coming and is another way of prioritising as it gives you the probability that a vulnerability will be exploited whilst not perfect, it should help as another method if your faced with thousands to fix.You can make this very complex or keep it simple but effective and you can waste time focusing on critical cves on internal systems while you have high rated ones on internet facing.
Would add: - exposure of the asset - is the affected asset part of your control plane e.g. VPN, EDR etc

Another angle is how easily the vulns can be mitigated. Say its a low score but trivial to patch and no extra burden on the IT team to do it, we knock those out priority. If its a completely manual patching process, or even "unpatchable", then we pretty much only glance at those for any criticals that are exposed/exploitable, then move on. We need action, so we find the most progress when we focus on actionable items. This all heavily depends on your org and the maturity of the program overall.

Google Cyber security risk assemmet matrix. You categorize everything you know and you determine the overall risk. You start with the highest risk stuff and work your way down to the lowest risk. Sometimes there's super low hanging fruit that can take your stuff high to medium/low risk by just enabling settings in software you already have. For example enabling 2fa is a simple fix that can knock down the probability a point and in turn lower your overall risk.You have to remember when doing these type of risk assessments is if everything is high risk then nothing is high risk so you have to be realistic.

How do I gain NIST experience without having NIST experience?

Study NIST enough so that in an interview you can say something like:k"I haven't needed to use any NIST frameworks, however I would implement similar to how I've implemented <x> in the past. For example in <specific NIST doc> the section on <something> I would implement similar to <similar bit from framework you DO know>"

Is there a specific NIST SP that you are being asked about? 800-53, 800-171, RMF in general? I would imagine that you could do a crosswalk between the frameworks you are familiar with and identify the similarities. Maybe explain that while you aren’t experienced directly with NIST you have put in the legwork to find how your experience can map to what they are requesting. Obviously just an interview tactic to say while I don’t know the specifics of X, my experience in Y is attributable.

Reference SCF (free) and look for overlap between the different NIST standards the frameworks you have worked with. It’s not like the assessment process differs, it is just different standards. But when you look at PCI or whatever standards, there is a lot of overlap.
The frameworks map to each other almost completely…https://www.auditscripts.com/wp-content/uploads/dlm_uploads/2016/04/AuditScripts-Critical-Security-Control-Master-Mappings-v7.0d.xlsx

In interviews I like to ask people to describe their home network, and do a mini adhoc assessment and talk about some of the 800-53 or 800-171 controls they either applied or would recommend applying and why.You can take this a step further and build an actual home lab and practice auditing it and remediating findings. You don't even need to buy anything, start with what you already have and maybe some lightweight VMs.If you can even automate the remediation using a configuration management tool like chef, puppet, or ansible companies would love to see that. These days some cloud configuration automation is great too such as terraform. But these are all bonus items on top of what you asked.

Read and study. If you can speak it your in a better position. Heck, if you read it then you’re better off than most the people that supposedly practice it. I’ve never seen any company put in the investment to follow RMF as written.

Ask your business connections for an audit plan.These include the focused items for review and audit finding/conclusions support. Review it against the actual framework. Begin to review remediation steps for a wide variety of each control you're reviewing and see if it fits the context of the scope of the audit elements.If you want to really understand the framework, it's about understanding of how the org uses the control against the results produced. Policy and process alignment is another element to ask those who would supply the information.There are lots of frameworks which are aligned to NIST so remediations are plentiful. Use these to help give options best suited for tracking and follow up with notes to support the next auditor.

Absolutely. I work for a Cybersecurity Training Platform and I can tell you that anything you need to know about the NIST Framework is available with a simple Google search. Study it a good bit. As with MITRE or any other framework, it can get granular. You do not need that level of understanding, just be able to relate some of your knowledge to the framework allowing the interviewer to know that you are familiar. You can also find relationships to frameworks you do know, ie. MITRE ATTACK and speak to it as I have had much more familiarity with _________ framework, but I understand some correlations such as ___________.

You submit the form and references. Then the back ground check begins.The company will call all the references you listed as they are seeing if they can trust you. Are 2fa secrets even less secure than passwords, specifically in the event of a data breach?

The 2FA secrets, also known as "shared secrets," are typically stored on the server side in an encrypted form. Unlike passwords, which are usually stored as hashes, 2FA secrets need to be retrievable in their original form to generate One-Time Passwords (OTPs). Therefore, they are encrypted and stored securely on the server. The encryption key used to protect these secrets is typically stored separately.In the event of a data breach, the exposure of 2FA secrets is indeed a concern. If an attacker gains access to both the encrypted 2FA secrets and the encryption keys, they could potentially decrypt the secrets and generate valid OTPs. However, this scenario is less likely because gaining access to both the encrypted secrets and the keys simultaneously would require a very sophisticated attack, and most systems are designed to protect against such scenarios.

In most cases this means that attempts to tamper will zero the secret. The server you are logging into is not the authenticator and doesn’t not hold the secret. The authenticator must be hardened and protected from compromise. But since it only communicates with the servers using a specific protocol it can be much more difficult to compromise. In a proper implementation the secret is stored in an HSM and values are generated by the HSM on behalf of the authenticator. The valid number for authentication is algorithmically generated based on the secret and a synchronized value between the authenticator and the device.By capturing many authentication sessions in plaintext it may be possible to derive the algorithm and create a brute force attack, but this should by standard be more difficult than performing a brute force attack on a password.
